elements.text: Today we talked about the life cycle. Then we read the book
We’ve learned that all living things have a life cycle. Now let’s make sure we know how to tell the difference between living things and things that are not living.
Remember, living things change as they grow—that’s the life cycle.
I’ll show you a picture card, and you tell me whether it shows something that is living or not living. We’ll put the living things in one column, and the nonliving things in another.
We can tell if something is living or nonliving by asking whether it grows and changes.
As we talk and share, we’ll come up with other ways to tell if something is living or not living.
Ask children to give a thumbs-up if the picture shows a living thing or a thumbs-down if it does not. Model.
Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the card to extend conversation.
Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Talk About Living and Non-Living Things

Some of these cards show objects that look like living things—like the puppet. When we play make-believe, we often use objects that are not living, like toys, and pretend they are living. How do we know these are not living things?
means “not living.” Help children understand that nonliving things do not grow and do not need air or water.

Consider comparing a dead tree and a flag pole to explore the concept of living things that have died. Ask if the tree is dead (yes), then ask if it is nonliving (yes). Ask the same about the flag pole. Remind children that before the tree died, it made a nut that grew into a new tree.

Allow children to use a physical response if they are not comfortable speaking. For example, invite children to physically move a card showing a living thing to the “living” column. Describe the child’s choice, asking questions like, “Are you putting the seed in the living column? That’s right! The seed can change and grow.”

Children who need sensory support may prefer to see and touch real examples of living and nonliving things. Set a seed, a potted plant, a puppet, and a rock on the table, and let the children move the objects to the appropriate columns as they discuss and handle them.

You will need the diagram on pages 26–27 of
Now we are going to look at some other plants. We’ll practice another Mind Builder, make connections, as we connect what we learned in the book to what we see in the pictures.
Remember, plants are living things. That means they go through a life cycle.
They change into seedlings. These seedlings grow long stems.
On the stems, buds open into leaves or flowers.
A new seed grows inside a flower or its fruit. The plant may dry up, but the seed can become a new plant.
Place the life-cycle diagram face up on the table.
Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend talk.
Continue the activity using the next picture card.
In most cases, we could connect the pictures we saw to the pictures in
Making connections can help you better understand hard topics.

Some children may need more help recognizing the stages of a life cycle of an unfamiliar plant. Be sure to show the picture of the bluebonnet flowers right before showing the picture of the same flowers gone to seed.

Pair up older children or those who need a greater challenge for peer-to-peer discussions about one or more picture cards. Have them discuss where their picture fits in the plant’s life cycle. Then ask them to share their ideas with the group.

Encourage multilingual learners to respond by placing each card near the corresponding stage in the life-cycle diagram. Encourage children to say whether the plant is near the beginning, middle, or end of the life cycle.

To give students an opportunity for gross motor activity and nature investigation, consider taking this activity outside in an area with plants and trees. Give each child a card, then send them off to find an example of something in a stage of life similar to the pictured object. Have them describe how the objects they found connect to the plants pictured. Ask them where their objects fit in a plant’s life cycle.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
The book talked about some of the things that help sunflower plants grow. These are things that all plants need to grow!
Let’s remember some of the things that sunflowers need to grow.
When they are seeds, they need water, sunlight, warmth, and soil.
As they grow into plants with leaves, they need sunlight, air, and water.
Flowers need pollen from other flowers to make new seeds. Bees help spread the pollen!
We’re going to look at pictures of people caring for plants. Some of the things might connect to what we learned in
You’ll act out what you see, and talk about it at the same time.
Show one picture card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the activity using the next picture card.
Sometimes plants get what they need from nature, but sometimes they need a little help. We can help care for plants.

Children may need sentence frames to express what they see in the pictures. They may also need help explaining some activities, like the work of the bees. Simply invite them to act like bees, and reinforce that bees are helpers!

Invite children who need a greater challenge to describe and act out plant care activities not shown on the card. For instance, composting food waste creates food for plants, weeding gives plants room to grow, and pruning or trimming helps plants grow strong and full.
Spanish speaking children may recognize cognates related to plants and plant care:
Encourage children to share these Spanish words with the whole class, and ask other children if they can identify the English cognates.

Some children may enjoy drawing, rather than acting out, the activities shown in the cards. Provide paper and drawing tools for these students, and encourage them to draw the plant care activity they find most interesting. Then ask them to talk about their pictures and share with the group.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
Today we heard the story of
We connected some things in that story to things we read in
Your brains love making connections, and they are really good at it. Let’s do an activity that can help us talk about those connections!

I’ll show you pictures that have two or more things in them. Then I’ll ask you to say how the two things are related, or connected. For example, I might show you a picture of a corn kernel and a corn cob. I’d ask,
The corn cob is bigger than the corn kernel.
Show one picture card to one child and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra challenge or support as needed.
Use the last question on the back of the card to extend conversation.
Continue the game using the next picture card with the next child.

Some of these words help us compare two things. When we compare, we can say how one thing is more, or less, than something else. Other words help us show how two things are related in space. We can say whether something was beside or on something else.
The words we’ve been practicing help you say what your brain is already doing—making connections! The more connections you make, the smarter you get.
, and show how it connects to the base word. For example, when teaching
mention a lion and an elephant. Say,

Children needing a greater challenge may find other relationships between the objects on the card, or between an object on the card and something else. As long as the child is generating language to show relationships, let them run with these connections!

Encourage multilingual learners to use a physical response to express the relationship between two objects. For example, set a small toy and an empty tissue box on the table. Let children place the toy inside, on, or next to the box. For
comparisons, invite the child to point to the relevant object in the picture. Encourage the child to use words, in English or the home language, to express the relationships between objects.

If children need attention support, allow all children to participate with each card. Show the card to the whole group, and ask the question on the back. Have students respond chorally to Support questions. Then give each child an opportunity to respond individually to the Extend question.
